nodes.text: Infant affectional bonding is primarily driven by contact comfort rather than by nursing or food-related drive reduction
Rhesus macaque infants are a valid experimental model for studying neonatal and infant affectional variables relevant to humans

We constructed artificial mother surrogates (cloth-covered terry cloth mother with warm sponge rubber body and single nipple, and a wire-mesh mother warmed by radiant heat) to isolate contact comfort from nursing

Experimental design: dual-mother condition with cloth and wire surrogates attached to infant cage; for half the infants cloth mother lactated, for the other half the wire mother lactated; time spent on each surrogate was automatically recorded and multiple behavioral tests were administered
In the dual-mother experiments infants overwhelmingly preferred the cloth surrogate over the wire surrogate regardless of which surrogate provided milk

Time-on-surrogate data across 165 consecutive days showed persistent preference for cloth mother and little responsiveness to wire mother, contradicting derived-drive (conditioning to nursing) accounts

Fear tests (moving toy bear) and open-field tests showed infants sought the cloth mother as a haven of safety; presence of cloth mother halved emotionality indices compared with mother-absent conditions

In baby Butler box visual exploration tests, infants responded strongly to cloth mother and other infant monkeys but not to wire mother or empty box, and this preference was independent of which surrogate lactated
Retention tests up to 185 days after separation demonstrated strong, long-lasting affectional bonds to the cloth surrogate with little waning of responsiveness, indicating resistance to extinction

Control group raised only on wire mother showed biologically adequate feeding and weight gain but displayed softer stools suggesting psychosomatic effects and exhibited less contact and security behaviors

Infants introduced to cloth and wire surrogates at 250 days (late introduction controls) initially showed fear and avoidance but within days developed strong preference and extensive contact with cloth mother, though intensity was lower than in animals mothered from birth
The experimental findings indicate nursing is a negligible variable for affection formation beyond serving to bring about body contact; contact comfort alone can generate strong, enduring attachment

Other candidate affectional variables (postural support, rocking, clinging, maternal sounds, visual face features, primary object following) likely contribute and merit systematic study using these techniques

Limitations and future directions: findings are based on macaque surrogates and engineered conditions; further work needed to compare real mother versus surrogate directly, study generalization of affection, and quantify roles of other variables
Practical implication: neonatal nursing may not be essential for affectional bonding and contact-based caregiving could substitute, with potential societal relevance for child-rearing practices
